questions.question: Which of the following statements about inverted papilloma is false?

options.B: Arises from the lateral wall of nose
options.D: Presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis

questions.question: A 46-year-old man presented with left-sided nasal blockage and discharge for 3 years. Onanterior rhinoscopy, a pale, red polypoidal mass is seen in the left nostril. He was diagnosedwith inverted papilloma. Which of the following statements is false about the management ofhis condition?

options.D: MRI is the first imaging modality in follow-up

questions.explanation: Radiotherapy is not advised in inverted papilloma since it may induce malignancy.Option A: Endoscopic approach is preferred to surgical resection.Option C: There is a high rate of recurrence of inverted papillomas.Option D: MRI is the first imaging modality to perform during follow up.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common malignant tumor of the nasal cavity?
questions.explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the nasal cavity, seen in about 80% of cases.

questions.question: Which of the following is also known as nose picker's carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma of the nasal cavity arising from the nasal septum is called nose picker'scancer.Option A: Inverted papilloma is also known as transitional cell papilloma or Ringertz tumor orSchneiderian papilloma.Option B: Basal cell carcinoma is also known as rodent ulcer.Option D: Esthesioneuroblastoma is also known as olfactory neuroblastoma.

questions.question: A 15-year-old presented with a cherry red, polypoidal mass detected on anterior rhinoscopy.Biopsy of the mass suggested that it originated from the olfactory neural epithelium. Which ofthe following is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario suggests the diagnosis of esthesioneuroblastoma. It arises from theolfactory epithelium of the upper third of the nose.

questions.question: A patient is planned for surgical resection of esthesioneuroblastoma. Which of the following statements is false about the same?

options.D: Lymph node metastasis does not occur

questions.explanation: Lymph node metastasis occurs in 10-15% of the cases.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common site for osteomas?
questions.explanation: Osteomas are most commonly seen in the frontal sinus followed by ethmoid and maxillarysinuses.They remain asymptomatic and are incidentally found on x-rays. Treatment is required only whenthey cause obstructive symptoms or pressure effects.410The image given shows the x-ray image of an osteoma in the frontal sinus.

questions.question: The most common site of occurrence of fibrous dysplasia is405
questions.explanation: The maxilla is the most common site for fibrous dysplasia.Fibrous dysplasias and ossifying fibromas are both skeletal lesions where normal architecture isreplaced by vascularized fibrous tissue.However, the difference between the two is as follows -Fibrous dysplasiaOssifying fibromaSiteMore common in the maxilla.More common in the mandibleRadiologyPathologyNo well-defined edge, lesionmerges with surroundingsStrongly reactive for osteocalcinWell demarcated lesionWeakly reactive for osteocalcin

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common site for ossifying fibroma?
questions.explanation: The mandible is the most common site for the occurrence of ossifying fibroma.Fibrous dysplasias and ossifying fibromas are both skeletal lesions where normal architecture isreplaced by vascularized fibrous tissue.However, the difference between the two is as follows -411SiteRadiologyPathologyFibrous dysplasiaMore common in the maxilla.No well-defined edge, lesionmerges with surroundingsStrongly reactive for osteocalcinOssifying fibromaMore common in the mandibleWell demarcated lesionWeakly reactive for osteocalcin0.0

questions.question: A patient is referred to the ENT OPD with left-sided nasal obstruction, disfigurement of theface, and displacement of his left eye. Imaging of paranasal sinuses shows an ill-definedexpanding lesion with ground glass appearance in the maxillary sinus. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The diagnosis is fibrous dysplasia. A ground-glass appearance in CT or x-ray is characteristic offibrous dysplasia.In fibrous dysplasia, bone is replaced by fibrous tissue. The most common site is the maxillarysinus, followed by the ethmoid and frontal sinuses.It can present with disfigurement of the face, nasal obstruction, and displacement of the eye.The x-ray image below shows a ground-glass appearance present in the left maxillary sinus due tofibrous dysplasia. The lesion is not well demarcated and merges with the surrounding area. Thereis orbital displacement on the left side.412R

questions.question: Which of the following histological varieties is the most common among paranasal sinuscarcinomas?
questions.explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the paranasal sinuses.

questions.question: 406Where is squamous cell carcinoma most commonly found in the paranasal sinuses?
questions.explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common in the maxillary sinuses followed in turn byethmoids, frontal and sphenoid sinuses.

questions.question: A carpenter was diagnosed with sinonasal carcinoma and planned for surgical resection.Which of the following histological varieties would be most likely in this case?
questions.explanation: Adenocarcinoma is the most common variety in this case. Workers of the furniture industry orwoodworkers develop adenocarcinoma.It is most commonly found in the ethmoid sinuses and upper nasal cavity.Workers engaged in nickel refining may develop squamous cell carcinoma and anaplasticcarcinoma.

questions.question: Which of the following is an early feature of maxillary carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Blood-tinged nasal discharge is an early feature of maxillary carcinoma.Other early features include:• Nasal stuffiness413• Facial paraesthesias• Pain●Epiphora.These symptoms may be missed or simply treated as sinusitis.Option B: Lymphatic spread occurs in the late stages of the disease. Among the cervical lymphnodes, submandibular and upper jugular lymph nodes are enlarged.Option C: Proptosis is a late feature that occurs after the invasion of the orbit.Option D: Dental pain is a late feature that occurs due to expansion of the alveolus after the tumorspreads inferiorly.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is classified using Ohngren's classification?
questions.explanation: Ohngren's classification is used for maxillary carcinoma.An imaginary plane is drawn, extending between medial canthus of eye and the angle of mandible.Ohngren's line(below image):Ohngren's classification ofMaxillary carcinomaMAMaxillarysinusOMARROWGrowths situated above this plane (suprastructural) have a poorer prognosis than those below it(infrastructural).

questions.question: 407A 43-year-old factory worker presents to you with nasal obstruction, cheek swelling, anddiplopia. The ENT resident suspects maxillary carcinoma and uses the following image toclassify the same. Which one of the following classification systems are used?
questions.explanation: Ledermann's classification is used to classify maxillary carcinoma in this case.It uses two horizontal lines of Sebileau; one passing through the floors of orbits and the otherthrough floors of antra.414Ledermann's classification ofmaxillary carcinomaSuprastructureMeso-structureInfrastructureOMARROWOrbitEthmoid, sphenoid,frontal sinuses andolfactory area ofnose.Maxillary andrespiratory part ofnoseAlveolar process

questions.question: You have a patient with maxillary sinus carcinoma. Which of the following lymph nodes will be most commonly involved?
questions.explanation: The submandibular and jugulodigastric nodes are the most commonly involved in maxillary sinus carcinoma. Maxillary and ethmoid sinus drain primarily into retropharyngeal nodes, but these nodes are inaccessible for palpation.

questions.question: In a known case of maxillary carcinoma, histopathology of the surgically resected regionshows that the tumor has eroded into the floor and medial wall of the orbit and the frontalsinus. Which of the following is the best management strategy?408
questions.explanation: Radiotherapy is preferred here, as in this case surgery has already been performed. The tumorstaging is T4 by AJCC classification.T3 and T4 lesions are treated by combined modalities of radiation and surgery. Radiation in suchcases may be given preoperatively or postoperatively.T1 and T2 lesions without nodal or distant metastasis are treated with surgery or radiation withequal results.StagDescriptionT1Tumour restricted to maxillary sinusmucosaT2Bony erosion- extension intohard palate or middle meatus,except posterior wall and pterygoid plates415StagT3T4aT4bDescriptionInvasion intosuprastructuressuch as: Posterior wall of maxillary sinusSubcutaneous tissues Floor or medial wall of orbitPterygoid fossaEthmoid sinusTumour invades any of the following: Anteriororbital contentsThe skin of the nose or cheekInfratemporal fossaPterygoid platesCribriform plateSphenoid or frontal sinusesTumour invades any of the following:Orbital apexBrain/duraMiddle cranial fossaNasopharynx416
